prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues examined a proposed multi-layer network depicting social interactions among people that could lead to infection. The network consists of different social layers, with each layer representing a specific type of interaction. The nodes in the network are individuals, and the weighted connections between them indicate the likelihood of transmission based on a probability value ranging from 0 to 1. The first layer of the network focuses on home interactions and is made up of groups of varying sizes. These groups are internally connected but have no external connections, resembling disconnected components representing families. The size distribution of Argentine families in 2009 was used to create these groups, with probabilities assigned to family sizes ranging from 1 to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context:
. A considerable portion of the population in any country must engage in some form of economic activity, which involves interacting with others. Work is a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model work activity, we suggest a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's total population. Due to the diverse range of jobs and companies, defining connection rules that accurately mirror reality is challenging. In a typical scenario, we assume random group sizes ranging from 5 to 30 individuals in an internally connected network similar to the "home" layer. This layer is illustrated in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100, with virus transmission influenced by edge weights, as detailed in Section 3.1.1.

Public transportation is crucial in urban areas but poses a risk for virus spread due to high congestion. Our third proposed layer represents public transport users, accounting for 50% of the population between those in capitals and other cities in Argentina. Passenger groups are randomly formed with sizes ranging from 10 to 40 individuals, each fully connected internally. The average daily use of public transport in Argentina is around 1.2 hours, emphasizing the significance of this layer in modeling an epidemic scenario.

original_post_context: . A large fraction of the population in any country need to work or practice some kind of economic activity, which means interacting with other people. Thus, work represents one of the most important factors of social relations, which is also very important in an epidemic scenario. To represent the work activity, we propose a generic layer to connect people with ages from 18 to 59 years, i.e., 60% of the total population in the case of Brazil. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using n = 100. Although the nodes of a group are fully connected, the transmission of the virus depends directly on the edge weights, which we discuss in-depth on Section 3.1.1. Collective transports are essential in most cities but are among the most crowded environments and play an important role in an epidemic scenario due to the possibility of geographical spread, as vehicles are constantly moving around. The third layer we propose represents these public transports that include people who do not possess or use a personal vehicle. In Brazil the number of people using public transport depends on the size of the city, with 64.98% in the capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], with an average use of around 1.2 h a day.1 Here we consider the average of the population between the two cases (50%), randomly sampled, to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups are created with sizes between [10, 40], uniformly sampled, and the nodes within each group are fully connected. author: chunwei
pre_context: In their study, eiva et al. (2021) examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including the increase and decrease of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The social network model used in the study initially assumed all layers and original infection probabilities. The infection started at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread over daily iterations up to 300 days. The researchers considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1, reflecting natural social distancing and preventive measures. The study found that this initial β value produced results more closely aligned with the Argentinian pandemic data. A moderate quarantine was implemented after 27 days, mimicking measures enforced by Argentinian states like Buenos Aires on March 24. During this quarantine period, certain activities were restricted, and contacts on transports and at workplaces were reduced to 30% of their initial level (β = 0.09). The study analyzed how the β parameter affected the overall epidemic trend, with higher infection rates leading to quicker spread of the disease but also resulting in faster natural immunization of recovered individuals.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinian epidemic (up to May 17) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher variation in the number of diagnosed cases in the past ten days may be due to increased testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels (which have been below 50% for most days in the past month) [43]. Our analysis assumes a fixed isolation level similar to what was observed in the early days after government decrees in Argentina. However, data suggests that isolation levels are constantly changing, indicating that the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may exceed those reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). Regarding daily death tolls, the average number from our model is higher than official figures, likely due to higher underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. A comparison of death numbers in Argentina from January 1 to April 30 in 2019 and 2020 (shown in Fig. 5) reveals a clear upward trend starting on February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina. This suggests that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported.

Looking ahead after the initial stage of the epidemic, we consider four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (by May 26): maintain current isolation levels without changes; lift isolation measures and return to normal activities (initial network layers and weights); only resume work activities while maintaining initial layer probabilities; or increase isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.
original_pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 the effects of different actions on the overall epidemic picture, such as the increase and reduction of cases, deaths, and occupied beds in hospitals. The social network starts with all its layers and the original infection probabilities. The infection begins at a node with the closest degree to the average network degree and propagates at iterations of 1 day (up to 300 days). We consider an optimistic scenario in which people are aware of the virus since the beginning, thus the initial infection probability is β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e., β = 0.09. The remaining activities on these layers represent services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are kept taking higher precautionary measures and disrespecting the quarantine. Under this scenario, we first analyze how the β parameter impacts the overall epidemic shape. Fig. 4(a) shows results for 4 β values in function of daily new cases and deaths, iterating from up to 300 days after the first infection. As higher the infection rates, faster is the disease spreading and the final number of cases and deaths. On the other hand, the epidemic ends faster due to natural immunization of recovered nodes. 4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using

The model achieves a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be related to the increase in Brazil's tests. Or yet, the constant decrease of isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days of the past month) [43]. We considered here a fixed isolation level around what was observed in the first days after the government decrees in Brazil. Still, data from the same reference show that these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths for the remaining simulation may be higher than the reported on this paper (see the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section). Concerning the daily death toll, the average number of the proposed models is higher than that of the official numbers. This is somehow expected, considering that the underdetection rates may be higher in contrast to the fewer number of tests being performed. To better understand this, we analyzed the number of death in Brazil from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases between 2019 and 2020; the results are shown in Fig. 5. It is possible to observe a clear increasing pattern after February 26, which is the day of the first officially confirmed case of COVID-19 in Brazil, indicating that the real death toll may be significantly higher than the official numbers. 4.2. Future actions and its impacts After the initial epidemic phase, we consider four possible actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Do nothing more, maintaining the current isolation levels; b) Stop isolation, returning activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Return only work activities, restoring the initial probability of the layer; or d) Increase isolation, stopping the remaining activities in work and transport

In Fig. 5, we analyzed the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Peru by comparing official death records from 2019 and 2020 within the same timeframe (January 1 to April 30). This comparison was made against COVID-19 records from the WHO and the Peruvian government. A notable difference emerging after the first confirmed case suggests a significant underdetection of COVID-19 cases. When all activities are resumed, taking into account growth, peak, and decline times, the final figures show 1,253,119 (± 26,009) diagnosed cases and 197,756 (± 5,693) deaths. Implementing a strict lockdown after 90 days results in a considerable decrease in infection and death counts compared to other strategies. Recovery time is also expedited, as daily new cases taper off sooner than in other scenarios. The peak of daily new cases occurs around day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, the total diagnosed cases and deaths are 552,855 (± 195,802) and 87,059 (± 30,871) respectively. Utilizing the hospitalization timeline outlined in Fig. 3, it is possible to estimate the number of occupied beds for regular hospitalization (severe cases) and ICU/Ventilation (critical cases). Additionally, we illustrate the difference between the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases, along with recovered cases. The methodology employed mirrors the previous 10 cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. examined the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Maintaining current isolation measures, (b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or (c) Increasing isolation by stopping work and public transportation. Testing capacity is limited by either a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus that outpaces testing capabilities. In their analysis, the researchers only considered diagnosed hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days from the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, with schools and religious activities suspended, while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity (achieved by further reducing the β term). Various actions were then considered 90 days after the first case, including maintaining the current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation and returning all activities to 100%, or only returning work activities. The findings indicate that maintaining the current isolation levels would result in a prolonged spread, approaching the estimated peak around June 5, with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, it is projected that there could be 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity around June 11, although the efficient implementation of new ICU beds and logistics management could help control the situation. It is important to note that this scenario assumes that social isolation remains above 50%, as it was at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Argentina's social isolation levels currently remain at 12%, highlighting the challenging circumstances.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, researchers examined the impact of different isolation scenarios on the spread of infection over a 90-day period. The study considered three scenarios: maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing limitations were a factor, with only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases were not identified and continued to spread the virus. The study also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals isolating themselves at home when experiencing symptoms, and severe cases being isolated in hospitals.Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of

post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered. This model is used in both Scenarios 1 and 3 to depict the infection rate resulting from compulsory mask wearing. Adjustments are made to Equation (9) to account for the gradual noncompliance with universal masking as individuals may become less compliant due to complacency and pandemic fatigue. The modified equation (10) shows a gentle transition in the infection rate from enforced mask-wearing to noncompliance, with a slight increase in the infection rate (βnc) as noncompliance increases. original_post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered. This model is used in both Scenarios 1 and 3. Figure 1. Logistic function to model the infection rate due to compulsory mask wearing m(t) for Scenarios 1 and 3. To model the gradual noncompliance of universal masking, we make a modification to Equation (9). m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k1(−t+t0) + βc − βnc 1 + e−k2(−t+t1) + βnc (10) As individuals began to engage in noncompliance out of complacency and pandemic fatigue, the infection rate, βnc, would thus increase slightly. Furthermore, compared to quenching of the infection rate due to enforcement of the compulsory mask wearing, the noncompliance will be gradual. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and t1 = 154, taken in context to Singapore's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. The infection rate βnc is expected to be lower than βs as even with the complacency and fatigue, as there is now a greater situational awareness of the severity and the population in general will take a more cautious outlook compared to pre-pandemic days.

Epidemiological Parameters To conduct our analysis in the Malaysia context, we estimate the epidemiological parameters described in the earlier sections for Malaysia's context: • • • •
post_context: : According to the position statement released by the National Centre of Disease Control Malaysia [21], a person remains infectious for up to 11 days after first contracting COVID-19.When conducting this study, we found that the SARS-CoV2 virus has an incubation period of about 5 days. The fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals, was 0.000064 at the time of this research, with 26 deaths and a total of 40,625 in the Recovered and Dead compartments in Malaysia. Due to the variability of this rate across different demographics and its unpredictable nature, we were unable to calculate a proper average. Therefore, for analytical purposes, we set it at 9 days. When analyzing the dynamics of delaying the mandatory use of masks using SEIR models with different scenarios, we obtained Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. The results showed that earlier enforcement of mask wearing reduced the Maximum Infected Value and prolonged the time taken to reach it. This is evident from the rightward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The Infected number rises until it reaches a global maxima before declining, as predicted by compartmental models.

Results and Discussion 6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing Upon applying the SEIR models to the 3 scenarios described in the above sections, we are able to obtain Maximum Infected Values by simulating different values of delay in mask enforcement. Considering the most basic case of Scenario 1; where there is complete compliance throughout the duration of mask enforcement, and the absence of time-limited immunity, Figure 3 shows the cases where mask wearing were to be enforced (a) on the day the first case of COVID-19 was detected in Singapore; (b) after a 50 days delay; (c) after a 100 days delay; and (d) not enforced at all. From Figure 3, it can be deduced that earlier enforcement of mask wearing both reduces the Maximum Infected Value as well as increases the number of days taken to reach the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. post_context: : Fatality rate is defined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals. During the time of this research, Malaysia had reported 26 deaths and a combined total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to significant variations in mortality rates among different demographics and the unpredictable nature of these statistics, it is not feasible to calculate an accurate average. Given the low number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia, determining an average using this small sample size would not be meaningful. Therefore, for analytical purposes, a value of 9 days was used. The results and discussion section focused on analyzing the impact of delaying the implementation of compulsory mask wearing. By utilizing SEIR models in three scenarios, different levels of delay in enforcing mask wearing were simulated to determine the Maximum Infected Values. The findings revealed that earlier implementation of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also extends the time taken to reach this peak. This shift is illustrated by a lower peak value and a rightward movement of the peak of the Infected compartment curve. The Maximum Infected Value represents the highest point of infection before a decline occurs in accordance with compartmental models. For instance, when mask wearing was enforced immediately upon detection of the first COVID-19 case (Scenario 1a), the Maximum Infected Value was around 10.453% on day 291. Conversely, with a 50-day delay (Scenario 1b), the Maximum Infected Value increased slightly to approximately 10.479%, with the peak occurring on a later day.

The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. post_context: [25].To explore the effects of delayed public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers related to the B117 variant, we conducted a hypothetical scenario analysis. We adjusted our simulation to reflect the characteristics of the B117 variant and examined three scenarios outlined in previous sections. The resulting data is presented in Figures 6 and 7, illustrating the maximum infection rates in relation to delays in mask enforcement for different scenarios. Additionally, we compared our findings to a study by Eikenberry et al. (3) which focused on similar mathematical modelling in the US states of New York and Washington. While their study showed comparable results with ours, our research in Singapore provides a more accurate representation for smaller city states. Furthermore, our study takes into account factors such as newer virus strains like the B117 variant and time-limited immunity which were not considered in the previous research.

original_post_context: [25]. To investigate the impact of delay in public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers due to the B117 variant, we modelled a hypothetical scenario. In this scenario, the first case of COVID-19 detected in Singapore is of the B117 variant. We ran our simulation of the 3 scenarios described in the preceding sections with a new value of R0 reflecting that of B117. The resulting plots are shown in Figure 6 and 7. Figure 6. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case. Figure 7. Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance for the B117 variant case. 6.3. Related Studies Juxtaposing our study against other similar studies that implement mathematical modelling on 'what-if' scenario based analysis, Eikenberry et al. [3] implemented a compartmentalized models for their simulations, and concluded that if the population remains unmasked until mask enforcement after some discrete delay, and that the level of adoption is fixed, the delay initially had little impact on the hospitalized fraction or deaths, but states that a 'point of no return' can be crossed. While this study yields similar results to ours, it is contextualised in the US states of New York and Washington, whilst ours was conducted in the context of Singapore. Given the differences in epidemiological parameters, size and characteristics of these cities and Singapore, our study adds value in being a more accurate representation of smaller city states. Furthermore, this study did not take into consideration newer, more infectious strains of the virus such as the B117 variant and time-limited immunity, which we have considered in our study.

Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively lower the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Nanchang on reducing infections in Beijing is comparable to increasing quarantine by a significant amount. It is important to evaluate the effectiveness and sustainability of the costly measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV. Introduction Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the family of Coronaviridae [1]. They cause generally mild respiratory infections, even though they are occasionally lethal. Since their discovery and first characterization in 1965 [2], three major, large-scale outbreaks have occurred, caused by emerging, highly pathogenic coronaviruses, namely, the "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome" (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in mainland China [3], the "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome" (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia [4,5] and the MERS outbreak in 2015 in South J. .As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital, resulting in an R(0) value of 2. Additionally, 739 individuals were placed in quarantine, resulting in an Sq(0) value of 739. Setting H(0) as 1 corresponds to the confirmed case reported on January 10, 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, leading to a rate of λ = 1/14. According to the WHO, the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, therefore σ = 1/7.

Likelihood-based estimations for Rc during the Hubei outbreak show a mean value of 6.39 with a mean and variance generation time of 6 and 2 days based on revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number estimated likelihood-based ranges from 1.66 to 10, showing sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Estimations based on a different revised data series (dataRev2) yield a mean value of 6.32 with the same mean and variance of generation time. The estimates from both time series align well, allowing for the use of either series to fit the proposed transmission model. In this study, estimations based on dataRev1 are chosen as reference for comparison and validation of the model-based estimation. Consequently, the revised dataset (dataRev1) will be used to fit the proposed model in the following sections of the manuscript.

As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set H(0) = 1, corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, thus λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Likelihood-Based Estimates Likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the outbreak in Wuhan gives a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days on the basis of a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number based on likelihood-based estimation ranges from 1.66 to 10 and it follows from Table 2 that Rc is sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to the other revised data series (dataRev2) gives a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time of 6 and 2 days. Note that the estimates of Rc based on the two time series agree well, and consequently, both revised data series can be used to fit the proposed dynamics transmission model. In this study, we chose the estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate our model-based estimation. Thus, in the following sections of the manuscript, we will use the revised dataset (dataRev1) to fit the proposed model.

post_context: .We began by setting H(0) = 1, representing the first confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The isolated individuals were kept separate for 14 days, resulting in a rate of λ = 1/14. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is around 7 days, resulting in σ = 1/7. The likelihood-based estimation of Rc during the Nanchang outbreak yielded an average value of 6.39, with a mean and variance of the generation time being 6 and 2 days based on revised data set dataRev1. The reproduction number estimates range from 1.66 to 10, highlighting Rc's sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Analysis of another revised data set (dataRev2) produced a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time again being 6 and 2 days. The estimates of Rc from both data sets align well, allowing both to be used for fitting the proposed transmission model. For consistency, we will use the estimates based on dataRev1 as the reference for verifying and validating our model-based estimation in the subsequent sections of our study.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method proposed by White and Pagano to estimate key parameters. Specifically, we used a formula that considers the generation interval and the total number of cases on each day. The generation interval was assumed to follow a gamma distribution with mean and variance values. To assess the impact of different mean values on the basic reproduction number of the 2019-nCoV, we varied the mean value from 2 to 8 days. The estimated values are presented in Table 2, showing the sensitivity of the reproduction number to different mean values.

Simulation: The population of Hubei is around 11,081,000 inhabitants [18], hence, we set S(0) = 11,081,000. As of 10 January 2020, two patients had been recovered and were subsequently discharged from the hospital leading to R(0) = 2, and 739 individuals were quarantined leading to Sq(0) = 739. We set
post_context: , corresponding to the reported confirmed case on 10 January 2020. The individuals in quarantine were separated for a period of 14 days, resulting in a daily transmission rate of λ = 1/14. The World Health Organization (WHO) states that the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is approximately 7 days, leading to a daily transmission probability of σ = 1/7. Likelihood-based estimates show that the reproduction number (Rc) during the Hubei outbreak had a mean value of 6.39, with a mean generation time of 6 days and a variance of 2 days based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The Rc ranged from 1.66 to 10 and was found to be sensitive to changes in mean generation intervals. Another data series (dataRev2) yielded a mean Rc of 6.32, with the same mean and variance of generation time. The estimates from both data series were in agreement, allowing them to be used to fit a proposed transmission model. The study selected the estimates from dataRev1 as the comparison reference for validation purposes, and subsequent sections of the manuscript will use this revised dataset for model fitting.

Likelihood-Based Method for Estimation

In our study, we utilized the likelihood-based method or generation interval-informed method developed by White and Pagano [23], as expressed in the formula below:

L(Rc, p|N) = T∏ t=1 exp(−φt)φNt t Γ(Nt + 1) (3) where φt = Rc ∑j=1 pjNt− j, k is the maximum value of the serial interval (set as k = 6 in this case), and Γ(x) represents the gamma function. The variable N = {N0, N1, . . . , NT}, where Nj indicates the total number of cases on day j and T is the final day of observations. The probability function pj represents the generation interval on day j, assumed to follow a gamma distribution with mean E and variance V. To account for uncertainty regarding the generation interval of the 2019-nCoV, we explored the impact of different E values ranging from 2 to 8 days on the estimated value of Rc.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The formula used to estimate the basic reproduction number (Rc) for the 2019-nCoV in Beijing, China involves a complex calculation that takes into account the generation interval probability function and sensitivity to different mean values (E) of the generation interval. In order to conduct simulations, data on the population of Beijing, the number of recovered patients, and the number of quarantined individuals are taken into consideration. The analysis indicates that the population size, recovery rate, and quarantine duration all play a significant role in determining the spread and impact of the virus. According to the WHO [24], the incubation period of 2019-nCoV is about 7 days, hence σ = 1/7. 3. Results 3.1. Before the Chinese New Year (25 January 2020), there were lots of annual summing-up meetings and/or parties, with higher than usual close contacts, leading to a higher likelihood of infection transmission than that of the earlier periods covered by other studies. Furthermore, we noted that more recently published studies based on datasets during periods comparable with ours reported similar findings in terms of a high basic reproduction number (for instance, Reference [29], where authors, using an exponential growth method, computed a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16), assuming no changes in reporting rate and with a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days). Variability in the estimation of the basic reproduction number is also a well-known methodological issue, and standardized methods both for calculating and reporting it are still lacking [30]. During the initial phases of an epidemics outbreak, only small datasets/time-points can be used. Some crucial information may be missing, and the quality, accuracy and reliability of data improves over time. In these situations, estimations are highly dependent on the specific datasets utilized and revising/updating such datasets could influence the results. We note that several key clinical parameters could be inferred from relevant clinical data based on sero-epidemiological surveys, and the possibility of spreading the infection from asymptomatic cases was only reported recently [31]. pre_context: Using the exponential growth method, a basic reproduction number of 6.11 (95% CI 4.51–8.16) was calculated, assuming a constant reporting rate and a serial interval of 8.4 ± 3.8 days. Estimating the basic reproduction number can be challenging due to variability and the lack of standardized calculation methods. Initial data on epidemic outbreaks may be limited and may improve in quality over time. Depending on the specific datasets used, estimations may vary, highlighting the importance of revising and updating data. Key clinical parameters can be inferred from sero-epidemiological surveys, and the potential spread of infection from asymptomatic cases has recently been recognized. The high reproduction number suggests the possibility of a severe epidemic without prompt public health interventions, especially during peak social contact times. The serial interval plays a crucial role in estimating the likelihood function accurately. The reported incubation period for coronavirus pneumonia in Chengdu patients ranges from 2 to 15 days. We then assume that the serial interval follows the gamma distribution with varying mean and variance, which allows us to examine the influence on the reproduction number. With the distribution of serial interval with mean 6 days and variance 2 days, the likelihood-based estimation of the reproduction number is consistent with the model-based estimation. It shows that longer serial intervals induce greater reproduction numbers, and hence, more new infections, which further confirms that the epidemic may be more serious than what has been reported until now [15]. Following the outbreak of coronavirus in Hubei, China on 23 January 2020, various measures such as travel restrictions in different regions and the introduction of new detection technologies have been implemented. However, the current model used for predicting future epidemic trends needs to be revised as the basic reproduction number estimated is no longer accurate. A forthcoming article will focus on this revision. The table below shows predictions of confirmed cases compared to real data. It is observed that coronaviruses can lead to major outbreaks with reproduction numbers ranging from 2.0 to 4.9. The ongoing fourth large-scale outbreak from Hubei, China to neighboring provinces and other countries emphasizes the need for more epidemiological data to effectively implement public health interventions like contact tracing, quarantine, and travel restrictions. 

In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. We found that the basic reproduction number could be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23), which seems consistent with the special period prior to the Spring Festival when contacts were higher than usual, and with the opinion that the virus has gone through at least three–four generations. It is worth mentioning that our model made a very good prediction of the confirmed cases from 23 to 29 January 2020, as shown in Table 4. Particularly, the predicted confirmed cases should be 7723 as of 29 January 2020, which is very close to the
post_context:
.

Moreover, our model predicts that the outbreak will reach its peak within two weeks under the strictest measures implemented since January 23, 2020, with a significantly low peak value. This study has important implications for public health decision-makers and policymakers. The high reproduction number indicates that the outbreak may be more severe than reported, especially during a season of increased social interactions, necessitating strict public health measures to mitigate the spread of the new virus. The authors have contributed to the conceptualization, methodology, software, data analysis, writing, review, and funding of the research. Conclusions Coronaviruses occasionally lead to major outbreaks, with documented reproduction numbers ranging from 2.0 to 4.9. Currently, a fourth large-scale outbreak is occurring and spreading out from Wuhan, Hubei province, China, to neighboring provinces and other countries. There is a dearth of epidemiological data about the emerging coronavirus, which would be of crucial importance to design and implement timely, ad hoc effective public health interventions, such as contact tracing, quarantine and travel restrictions. In this study, we adopted a deterministic model to shed light on the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus and assess the impact of public health interventions on infection. Furthermore, according to our model, the outbreak, under the most restrictive measures, is expected to peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020), with a significant low peak value. Our investigation has major practical implications for public health decision- and policy-makers. pre_context: The adjusted model revealed that the variation in COVID-19 severity among counties in Indiana is not solely due to population distribution, but also influenced by spatial factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five densely populated counties (Marion, Allen, Lake, Hamilton, and St. Joseph), with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties are major air travel hubs, receiving over 10 million passengers annually, which can lead to an influx of infections and accelerate local transmission. On the other hand, rural counties in Group 4 experienced lower infection rates due to their remote and less connected locations in Indiana. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Indiana, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite variations in healthcare capacity across different regions of the state, our modeling indicates that rural and less connected counties experienced lower transmission rates, preventing their critical care response from becoming overwhelmed. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions after early May would result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being reached, with some counties like Bartholomew, Dearborn, and Newton exceeding 50% capacity. When interventions are eased by 50%, our predictions show that 61% of the state's maximum critical care capacity could be reached within eight weeks, with areas experiencing more intense transmission reaching capacity more quickly. Counties with higher initial healthcare capacity would see their resources almost fully saturated (94% capacity) within the same timeframe. In contrast, rural and less connected counties in Group 4 would experience a slower spread of infection, allowing for better management of critical care resources.

pre_context: It is projected that by the end of 2021, approximately 680,000 individuals will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of those cases being asymptomatic. The infection rates peaked in December 2019 and March 2021, corresponding to spikes in new case counts. By the end of the year, 71% of the population in Ontario will have received at least one vaccine dose, with 57% fully vaccinated. Around 11,000 individuals are expected to have died from COVID-19 by the end of the year, with a breakdown of 36% from the wild type, 47% from the Alpha variant, and 17% from the Delta variant. Predicted population dynamics indicate a significant decrease in the susceptible population after December 2019, largely due to vaccination efforts. By the middle of 2021, only 37% of the population will remain susceptible, with most having received at least one vaccine dose. The number of active infections is expected to peak at the end of 2019, followed by a higher peak in the spring, driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven wave is expected to decrease as vaccination rates increase. Recovery rates are also expected to rise, with around 7% of the population predicted to have recovered by the end of 2021.These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. At that time, 11 K would have died from COVID, with 36, 47, and 17% from wild type, Alpha, and Delta, respectively (Fig. 2d). The year-end infection and death statistics are within 10% of reported data in Ontario (750 K infections and 10.2 K deaths)16. Predicted population dynamics are shown in Fig. 3. The drop in the susceptible population becomes significant after December 2020 (Fig. 3a) and is driven primarily by the vaccine deployment. By the end of June 2021, only 37% of the Ontario population are susceptible, with the majority having received at least one dose of vaccine (Fig. 3b,c). The number of active infections peaks at the end of 2020, followed by an even higher peak at the end of spring (Fig. 3d). These are the wild-type and Alpha-driven waves identified in Fig. 2a and described above. The Alpha-driven infection peak accounts for 0.7% of the total population, but subsides as the vaccination effort accelerates. The infections are split approximately half-half between asymptomatic and symptomatic ones, with the majority unvaccinated (Fig. 3d–g). As the infection spreads, the recovered population also increases, to 7% of the population at the end of 2021 (Fig. 3h). These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease. Given that the COVID-19 mortality rate can differ significantly based on the quality of healthcare infrastructure, we adjusted μW I by 50%. The immediate impact of changes in μW I on the number of deaths was consistent with expectations. However, the mortality rate, compared to other clinical aspects of SARS-CoV-2, only slightly affects the infected population, as less than 5% of them succumb to the virus.

Various provincial policies and pharmaceutical interventions, such as non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI), vaccination rate (ω1), dosing interval between vaccine doses (ω2), and vaccine escape rate (βW V), were taken into account in our analysis. NPI, by directly scaling βW, had a significant impact on the model's predictions, while the vaccination rate showed a lesser but still notable effect on disease transmission. Dosing interval and vaccine escape rate had relatively smaller effects, leading us to vary these parameters by 50%.

Among these factors, effective vaccine deployment (as captured in ω1) emerged as crucial in combating a pandemic, suggesting that success could still be achieved with a less-than-ideal vaccine with a higher escape rate. Notably, the model showed that prioritizing the first vaccine dose by extending the dosing interval, as seen in Canada, could be beneficial if vaccine supply is limited. Additionally, a sensitivity analysis of the full model incorporating all three variants revealed the effects of increasing key model parameters on the number of infections and deaths associated with each variant.

On the other hand, the dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) had smaller effects. Due to the potential wide variation in dosing interval within the population and the lack of well-defined characteristics for vaccine escape rate, these two parameters were varied by 50%. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population, and because vaccine escape rate is not sufficiently well characterized, these two parameters were varied by 50%. The vaccine-related results suggest that among these three factors, an effective vaccine deployment (captured in ω1) is the key in combating a pandemic, and success may be achieved even by means of a less-than-ideal vaccine with higher escape rate (Fig. 4). Since the predicted numbers of infections and deaths are substantially more sensitive to variations in ω1 than ω2, if vaccine supply is limited, prioritizing the first dose by lengthening the dosing interval would be advisable, as was done in Canada. In a second sensitivity analysis, we considered the full model that represents all three variants, using the baseline parameter values (Table S1). Key model parameters were increased to determine the effects on the number of infections and deaths associated with each variant. In addition to parameters considered in the above analysis, we also considered two parameters that mediate VOC interactions: βX R, rate of infection of individuals with partial immunity from having recovered from a different variant, and ηR, rate of loss of immunity due to infection. Some of these parameters have distinct values for each of the variants. Simulations were conducted by varying each of the parameter values for individual variants separately. author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates various parameters related to the viruses from January 1, 2019, to December 31, 2020. This includes the number of new infections on a 7-day average, cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, vaccination rates, and cumulative deaths. Even slight changes in these parameters can lead to significant impacts on infection and mortality rates, as shown in Figure 4. The mortality rate of COVID-19, in particular, plays a crucial role in the spread of the disease, with variations in this rate having immediate effects on the number of deaths. While mortality rate affects the infected population, other clinical features of the virus also play a role in determining outcomes. Various policy and pharmaceutical interventions, such as non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI), vaccination rates, vaccine dosing schedules, and vaccine efficacy, were considered in the analysis. λ and ω1 are varied by 5%. Since NPI are modelled by scaling βW directly, they have large effects on model predictions (Fig. 4). Vaccination rate has lesser but still significant effects on the spread of the disease. The effects of dosing interval (ω2) and
post_context: are much smaller. Because dosing interval can vary greatly within the population and the vaccine escape rate is not well characterized, both of these parameters were varied by 50%. The study's findings indicate that the most crucial factor in combating a pandemic is the effective deployment of a vaccine (represented by ω1), with success being possible even with a less-than-ideal vaccine that has a higher escape rate. The results show that prioritizing the first vaccine dose by extending the dosing interval, as was done in Canada, can be beneficial when vaccine supply is limited. Another analysis considered all three variants using baseline parameter values and increased key model parameters to assess their impact on infection and death rates. Additionally, two parameters mediating interactions between variants were included: βX R, the rate of infection among individuals with partial immunity from a different variant, and ηR, the rate of immunity loss due to infection. Simulations were conducted by individually increasing the values of specific parameters for each variant, including βX, σX, αX, γX, and ω1 by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI and βX R by four-fold to evaluate the effects on infections and deaths. These analyses provide insights into the potential impact of various parameters on pandemic management.

author: enrique
pre_context: Figure 5 illustrates the impact of varying model parameter values on total infections and deaths over a two-year simulation of interacting VOC dynamics. The parameters are adjusted individually for the wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. Changes in infections and deaths are compared for the different variants based on parameters such as virus infectivity, infection rate of recovered individuals from other variants, and mortality rate among others. The model assumes a distribution of Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines based on Ontario's vaccination statistics, with Pfizer offering stronger protection against all COVID variants, particularly Delta. The scenario of a higher proportion of AstraZeneca vaccines, similar to the UK18, is also examined.For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a).The projected total number of Delta infections and related deaths by December 31, 2021 is expected to be significantly higher at 62K and 882, respectively, compared to the baseline figures of 39K and 689. If the provincial vaccination rate drops to 67% by September 1, 2021, instead of the baseline of 74%, the number of Delta infections and deaths could increase by 75% by March 2022. With Ontario gradually reopening and in-person classes resuming in September, there is a consideration of reducing the Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions (NPI) assumption, which may lead to increased COVID-19 infectivity. This may be a result of pandemic fatigue, a desire for personal interactions, and potential outbreaks in schools. The scenario involves less stringent NPI starting from September 1, 2021.
original_pre_context: Figure 5.   Sensitivity of model predictions, measured by total infections and deaths, to increases in model parameter values, in a two-year simulation interacting VOC dynamics. Parameters are varied individually for wild-type (column a), Alpha (column b), and Delta (column c). Relative changes in the number of infections and deaths are then computed for wild-type (yellow bars), Alpha (red bars), and Delta (blue bars). Parameter examined include virus infectivity (β), rate of infection of individuals recovered from a different variant (βR), ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic infections (σ), degree of increased infectivity β (due to mobility) of asymptomatic infected individuals compared to symptomatic ones, mortality rate of infected individuals (μI), disease recovery rate (γ), rate of loss of immunity due to infection (ηR), vaccine escape rate (βV), NPI stringency (λ), dosing interval (ω2), vaccination rate (ω1). The baseline model assumes that 95% of the vaccines are Pfizer and 5% are AstraZeneca, consistent with Ontario vaccination statistics. What if a larger fraction of the vaccines were AstraZeneca, as is the case in the  UK18. A notable difference between the two vaccine types is that the Pfizer vaccine offers stronger protection than AstraZeneca against all COVID variants, especially Delta, after either one or two doses. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By the end of 2021, the model predicts
original_post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a). The total number of Delta infections and related deaths are also significantly higher, predicted to be 62 K and 882 at the end of 2021, respectively, compared to baseline values of 39 K and 689 (Fig. 7b,d). If the provincial vaccination rate were lower, such that by September 1 2021 only 67% of the population are vaccinated with at least one dose, compared to the baseline vaccinated percentage of 74% (Fig. 7c), the total number of Delta infections and deaths would increase by 75% by the end of March 2022; see Fig. 7b,d. Beginning mid-June 2021, Ontario began to gradually reopen, with in-person classes set to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the NPI that remain will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. What if that assumption is overly optimistic? Indeed, it is not uncommon to experience pandemic fatigue and crave personal interactions; also, there may be outbreaks in schools. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In comparison to the results shown in Figure 2, we found that the projected cumulative confirmed cases were higher and the peak time was delayed. In a previous study, we estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which is higher than other reported values. The WHO estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) calculated a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Various mathematical models have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Two studies in existing literature have also indicated under-estimation of coronavirus cases, with Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020) noting this issue. Zhao et al. (2020) estimated the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540), leading to a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). The investigation suggested an oscillation in the reproduction number between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10) in a previous version released on the bioRxiv pre-print server. The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-fold to 2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Hubei there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The basic reproduction number was calculated to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39-4.13), indicating that in order to halt the outbreak, it is necessary to block at least 58-76% of transmissions. Three additional models incorporating data from international travel have been developed: one by Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020), another by Kucharski et al. (Kucharski et al., 2020), and a third by Hubei and collaborators (Hubei, Leung, & Leung, 2020). Specifically, Imai and colleagues (Imai et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5-3.5). The reproduction number was found to range from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9-4.2 depending on various scenarios and levels of exposure. This number also varied from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7-4.3 based on different estimates of generation time. Figure 2 shows predictions and the impact of control measures on infection, assuming that parameters obtained from data collected between January 23rd and January 29th, 2020, including interventions, remain constant. (A-B) Decreasing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020; (C-D) Decreasing/increasing the susceptible population size as of January 29th, 2020.

Discussion In our previous article (Tang et al., 2020), we had estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which represents a higher value than those so far computed. For instance, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, Li and colleagues (Li et al., 2020) have computed a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9), while in several other mathematical models which have been so far devised and released as pre-prints or undergone peer-review and published, the reproduction number varies from 1.3 to 4.7. Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. Authors computed the number of under-reported coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540). Based on this estimate, the basic reproduction number was found to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an
original_post_context: (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Wuhan there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. The basic reproduction number was computed to be 3.11 (95% CI 2.39e4.13). In terms of public health implications, in order to stop the outbreak, at least 58e76% of transmissions should be blocked. There are three further models incorporating data from international travels: the models of Imai and coauthors (Imai et al., 2020), of Kucharski et al. (Kucharski et al., 2020) and of Wu and collaborators (Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). In particular, Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (uncertainty range: 1.5e3.5). Depending on the different scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure, the reproduction number was found to vary from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9e4.2. Depending on the different estimates of generation time, the reproduction number oscillated from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7e4.3. Based Fig. 2. Predictions and effect of control measures on infection based on assumption that parameters obtained from fitting the data from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 (and hence the interventions) remain unchanged. (AeB) Decreasing the minimum contact rate after January 29th, 2020; (CeD) Decreasing/increasing the susceptible population size as of January 29th, 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Different estimates of the reproduction number for COVID-19 have been calculated by various studies. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) found a slightly higher value of 2.2 with a 95% confidence interval from 1.4 to 3.9. Other mathematical models have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Some studies have also looked at the under-reporting of coronavirus cases, such as Zhao et al. (2020) and Read et al. (2020). Zhao et al. (2020) quantitatively assessed the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases and calculated 469 under-reported cases with a 95% confidence interval of 403 to 540. They found the basic reproduction number to be 2.56 with a 95% confidence interval of 2.49 to 2.63. Previous versions of the study reported a reproduction number ranging from 3.30 to 5.47, with the basic reproduction number showing a correlation with a 0-fold to 2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Chengdu there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. Three models incorporating international travel data are considered: one by Imai et al. (2020), another by Kucharski et al. (2020), and a third by Wu et al. (2020). Imai et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number of 2.6 (with uncertainty range from 1.5-3.5) depending on various scenarios and levels of zoonotic exposure, this number ranged from 1.7 to 2.6 to 1.9-4.2. Depending on estimates of generation time, the reproduction number varied from 1.3 to 2.7 to 1.7-4.3. Control measures may impact infection rates, such as decreasing contact rates or adjusting the size of the susceptible population. These predictions are based on data from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020.
original_pre_context: ch represents a higher value than those so far computed. For instance, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, Li and colleagues (Li et al., 2020) have computed a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9), while in several other mathematical models which have been so far devised and released as pre-prints or undergone peer-review and published, the reproduction number varies from 1.3 to 4.7. Within the existing literature, two studies estimated under-estimation of coronavirus cases: the investigations by Zhao and collaborators (Zhao et al., 2020) and by Read et al. (Read, Bridgen, Cummings, Ho, & Jewell, 2020). Specifically, Zhao and coworkers (Zhao et al., 2020) have assessed from a quantitative standpoint the under-reporting rate of coronavirus cases, modeling the epidemic growth curve using the exponential growing Poisson process. Authors computed the number of under-reported coronavirus cases to be 469 (95% CI 403e540). Based on this estimate, the basic reproduction number was found to be 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of the investigation, released in the bioRxiv pre-print server, the reproduction number was computed to oscillate between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10). The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Read and coauthors (Read et al., 2020) used a deterministic SEIR model, assuming coronavirus cases being Poisson distributed and with parameter inference being achieved by maximum likelihood estimation utilizing the Nelder-Mead optimization approach. According to the dynamics transmission model, an ascertainment rate of 5.0% (95% CI 3.6e7.4) was computed and, based on this, authors estimated that as of January 22nd, 2020 in Wuhan there were 14,464 (95% CI 6510e25095) infected individuals, and 21,022 (95% CI 11,090e33,490) infections. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The model was fitted to data on cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to February 1st, 2020. The projected numbers of infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed cases were analyzed. The reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9, based on the level of infectiousness. It was assumed that the novel virus would result in more mild-to-moderate cases compared to the SARS virus, with a reproduction number of 2.0 (uncertainty 1.4 to 2.3). Effective public health interventions blocking over 60% of transmission were found to be crucial in controlling and containing the coronavirus outbreak. Various studies, including those by Imai, Yu, and Kucharski, utilized different models and approaches to estimate reproduction numbers and determine necessary quarantine rates for control of the outbreak. Multiple datasets were used to provide real-time estimates and address the issue of unreliable data sources. Transmission was modeled as a random process, fluctuating and varying over the time. Similar to the model of Imai and coworkers (Imai et al., 2020), the risk of transmission and the risk of causing a large outbreak were modeled based on a negative binomial offspring distribution, with incubation and infectious period being Erlang distributed. Median reproduction number was found to oscillate between 1.6 and 2.9 before the introduction and implementation of travel restriction. (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Shanghai as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was determined to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1) in a study by Shen and colleagues (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020). Their transmission model predicted 8042 infections and 898 deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02%. The basic reproduction number was calculated at 4.71, which decreased to 2.08 by January 22nd, 2020. It is anticipated that the outbreak will significantly decrease within 77 days from its onset. Additionally, reducing the time from illness/symptom onset to isolation could have a substantial impact on reducing infected cases and deaths, as found in the study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020).

Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020) calculated a reproduction number of 2.2 using a stochastic model, while Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated a range from 2.90 to 2.92 using statistical methods. Zhang and Wang (Zhang & Wang, 2020) determined the time of the most recent common ancestor to be December 17th, 2019, with a reproduction number oscillating between 1.1 and 1.6. These varying results may stem from different methodological approaches utilized in the studies.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Efforts to control and contain the coronavirus outbreak would benefit greatly from a high percentage of transmission control. Recent studies by Imai et al. (2020) and Yu (2020) have estimated that a quarantine rate of over 90% among the infectious population is necessary for effective control. Kucharski et al. (2020) developed a stochastic SEIR model using the Euler-Maruyama algorithm with a 6-hour time-step and a transmission rate following a geometric Brownian motion. They estimated a time-varying reproduction number using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach and utilized multiple datasets to provide real-time estimates of transmission. The model, like that of Imai et al. (2020), considered the risk of transmission and causing a large outbreak, with transmission modeled as a fluctuating, random process. The median reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9 before travel restrictions were implemented.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). A study by Majumder and Mandl (2020) using the IDEA model found that each day reduction in the time from symptom onset to isolation could lower peak population size by 72-84% and decrease infected cases and deaths by 68-80%. The reproduction number ranged from 2.0 to 3.1 in their model. Other studies by Riou and Althaus (2020), Liu et al. (2020), and Zhang & Wang (2020) also estimated the reproduction number using different methods and datasets. These variations may be attributed to different assumptions, models, and data used. The reproduction number was observed to fluctuate over time, reflecting the changing dynamics of the outbreak and case reporting.

post_context: 1.56 7.65 0.25 0.580 0.001 0.94 0.27 0.5 3.5 1 0.3 Units day −1 dimensionless day −1 day −1 dimensionless dimensionless day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 day −1 The basic reproduction number R 0  is obtained as the spectral radius of F · V −1 , precisely, βρ1 (γa l + (cid:7) (cid:7) i (cid:7) h R 0 = h ) + (βγa l + β (cid:3) (cid:7) (cid:7) p (cid:7) h h ) ρ2 .In our simulations, using the parameters outlined in Table 1, we calculated a basic reproduction number of R0 = 0.945. This indicates that the epidemic outbreak in Nanjing was effectively controlled by the Chinese authorities. Analyzing the local stability based on the basic reproduction number, we found that certain equations in the system are uncoupled, allowing us to derive analytical results through direct integration. By keeping the total population size N constant, we can study the local stability of the model by examining the remaining coupled system of state variables E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables is given by J M = beta matrix, with eigenvalues obtained from a characteristic polynomial. The stability of the system can be assessed based on the roots of this polynomial.

Regarding local stability in relation to the basic reproduction number, the equations in system (1) can be analyzed separately from the remaining equations. Through direct integration, we can derive the following analytical results:

- A(t) = ∫(1-ρ1-ρ2)κE(s)ds
- R(t) = ∫(γiI(s)+P(s))H(s)ds
- F(t) = δi∫I(s)ds + δp∫H(s)ds

With the total population size N being constant, we have S(t) = N - [E(t) + I(t) + P(t) + A(t) + H(t) + R(t) + F(t)]. Consequently, the local stability of model (1) can be examined through the coupled system of state variables: E, I, P, and H. The Jacobian matrix associated with these variables is given by J M = β[-κ, κρ1, κρ2, 0; 0, -γa, 0, -i, ϖp, ϖlβ, 0, -γh], where the eigenvalues are determined by the characteristic polynomial Z(λ) = λ^4 + a1λ^3 + a2λ^2 + a1λ + a4, with coefficients a1, a2, a3, and a4 as defined in (3).

post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment, denoted as P(t), interacts with the human population N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has indicated that COVID-19 can be transmitted from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) individuals infected with the virus spread it to susceptible persons S(t) through close contact or by sneezing and coughing in their surroundings. Due to the pathogen's ability to survive in the environment for a period of time, individuals in close proximity to contaminated areas are at risk of exposure, especially in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before proper hygiene measures are in place. This leads to a progression from susceptible to exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period, and further to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infected population. The majority of infected individuals recover and move to the recovered population R(t). The interaction between the human population and pathogens in the environment is depicted in the SEIR-P model in Fig. 1, with parameters outlined in Table 1. This results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations in the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

pre_context: Mwalili and colleagues conducted a study that explored the complex interactions between humans and their environment in relation to the spread of SARS-CoV-2. The study involved the development of a mathematical model to simulate the transmission of the virus. The model divided the human population into different categories based on their susceptibility and infection status. It was observed that the virus could be transmitted through human-to-human contact as well as through the environment. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, were found to spread the virus to those they came in close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals coughed or sneezed without precautions, the virus could spread to the surrounding environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. The SEIR-P model in Figure 1 showcases the transmission of COVID-19, with a human (SEIR shown in yellow) and pathogen (P shown in green) compartmental model.
