prior_outline: Fig. 2 Shield immunity dynamics in a SIR model.
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the dynamics of shield immunity in a SIR model, showing the impact of different levels of shielding (α) on infectious case dynamics and the final state of the system. The parameters β=0.25 and γ=0.1 are used. It is important to consider interactions with patients in healthcare settings when implementing specific scenarios for healthcare workers. The baseline epidemiological parameters, age-stratified risk, and population structure can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 and 2 and in the code available on GitHub. Using these parameters, an outbreak is seeded with a single exposed individual and a shielding strategy is implemented once the outbreak reaches 0.1% total prevalence. Different transmission rates result in varying outbreak scenarios. Early estimates from Wuhan suggest a transmission rate within a 95% confidence interval between 2.1 and 4.5.30), putting our high-transmission scenario on the conservative end of estimated ranges. However, the of the high-transmission scenario we examine here is consistent with the range of 2.0–2.6 considered in ref. 5, and with the median of (95% CI, 2.04–2.77) as R0 ¼ I estimated via stochastic model fits to outbreak data in India that account for undocumented transmission28. Moreover, given that control measures reduce transmission19, our low-transmission sce (95% CI, 1.14–1.63) nario is consistent with estimates of in India from 24 January to 3 February after travel restrictions
post_context:
2:38 and other measures were implemented.The results presented in Figure 3 demonstrate that implementing shielding interventions can reduce the impact of an outbreak compared to a baseline scenario. In a population of 10,000,000 in a high-transmission scenario, the model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. Similarly, in a low-transmission scenario, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding, with majority of deaths occurring in individuals aged 60 years and older. These results are consistent with other COVID-19 models and data from outbreaks in Italy and India.

It is important to note that the effectiveness of shielding depends on the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, represented as αRshields. Factors such as demographic distribution, asymptomatic transmission, and duration of immunity also play a role in the population-scale effects of shielding. Populations with a right-shifted demographic distribution may benefit more from shielding. While our simulation focuses on shielding alone, additional measures such as social distancing and shelter-in-place orders can further decrease interaction rates and reduce the spread of the virus.

As in  the  simple  SIR  model,  shielding  on  its  own  could  potentially decrease epidemic burden across multiple metrics, decreasing both the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of size  10,000,000  for  the  high-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions are 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared with 58,000 deaths given intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths  given  enhanced  shielding  (α = 20).  In  a  population  of  size 10,000,000  for  the  low-transmission  scenario,  the  final  epidemic predictions from our model are 50,000 deaths in the baseline case compared  with  34,000  deaths  given  intermediate  shielding  and 8,300 deaths given enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths are of individuals aged 60 years and older, despite the lower fraction of individuals  in  those  ranges  (Fig.  3),  which  is  consistent  with  estimates in related COVID-19 models5,27,28 and from the outbreaks in Italy and China31. Our simulation results consider effects of shielding  alone,  whereas  ongoing  restrictions,  such  as  social  distancing and shelter-in-place orders, will help to further reduce interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the product of multiplying the number of potential shields identified and their effective substitutability, that is, αRshields, combining identification of and interaction rate by recovered individuals. The population-scale effects of shielding relies on multiple factors,  including  demographic  distributions,  the  fraction  of  asymptomatic transmission26,28 and the duration of immunity. We find that populations with a strongly right-shifted demographic distribution could  potentially  receive  increased  benefits  from  shielding. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In a research article published in 2020, Zhao and Chen modeled the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The study highlighted the unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the virus. The rapid spread of COVID-19 in China and several other countries was noted, underscoring the urgent need for effective measures to contain the outbreak.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hebei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hebei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.Estimates show that on February 12, 2020, Wuhan had 3,509 unquarantined infected cases, which dropped to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on the data from February 21, 2020, it is predicted that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hebei by late March, in China (excluding Hebei) by mid-March, and in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen by early March 2020. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected in China, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hebei (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions of China (excluding Hebei). These estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain stringent quarantine and control measures until early March in the tier-one cities and late March in Hebei. This model can be useful in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreaks, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. The disease has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during incubation, time delays between real dynamics and confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. A SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and predict epidemic trends using data from China, which can also provide guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreaks. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020
original_pre_context: y 2020, 8(1): 11–19 https://doi.org/10.1007/s40484-020-0199-0 RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in China Shilei Zhao1,2,3, Hua Chen1,2,3,4,* 1 CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China 2 China National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, China 3 School of Future Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China 4 CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, China * Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Received February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020 Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (
original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily numbers of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of quarantine and control measures. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. SUQC can also provide quantitative guidance for other countries in a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: RESEARCH ARTICLE: A study on modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India was conducted by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and more than 30 other countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effects of quarantine and control measures on interventions. The study was conducted by researchers from various institutes in India.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), India (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Delhi had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on this data, we predict that COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei will likely end by late March, in India excluding Hubei by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. In total, there are an estimated 80,511 infected individuals in India, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of India. These estimates are derived from a deterministic ODE model, so there may be some uncertainty. It is advised to maintain strict quarantine and control measures in place until early March in Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, and Chennai, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to predict the progression of the epidemic and offer guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in India and many other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between actual dynamics and confirmed cases, and the impact of interventions like quarantine. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and can be used to forecast the epidemic trend in India and other at-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. original_post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Background: COVID-19, the coronavirus disease 2019, has spread rapidly in China and to more than 30 countries in the last two months. It possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and the daily reported number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. 

Methods: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly account for the effects of intervention measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: By applying the SUQC model to the daily data of confirmed infections, we have analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hangzhou, Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), China (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in China. Our findings indicate that, prior to January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, suggesting that the implemented quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hangzhou estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hangzhou (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hangzhou on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hangzhou and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hangzhou, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hangzhou), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty. The recommendations are to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. The model can also be used to predict the epidemic trend and offer guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is spreading rapidly in China and several other countries. It has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period and delays between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases. Developed by the authors, the SUQC model analyzes the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from China to make predictions and provide guidance for countries at risk of outbreak. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over the last two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and parameterize the effectiveness of intervention measures. Results from applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data showed that regions like Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan), and four first-tier cities of China had a reproductive number R > 1 before January 30, 2020. However, after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been successful in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures remain in place until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and late March in Hunan. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. pre_context: Submitted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 possesses unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period and a time delay between the actual dynamics and the daily reported number of confirmed cases. To address this, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, explicitly considering the impact of implemented control measures. Our analysis of the data from Wuhan, Hubei, Japan, and four major Japanese cities using the SUQC model shows that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions had a reproductive number R greater than 1. However, following the implementation of quarantine and control measures, all regions saw a decrease in the reproductive number below 1, indicating the effectiveness of these measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). Please be aware that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of various interventions. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and applied it to Japanese data to predict the epidemic's trajectory. This model can also provide valuable insights for other countries at risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1B, there is a noticeable discrepancy between the projected total infection numbers and the confirmed infections in Chengdu. The local medical agency in Chengdu began using clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion after February 14th, resulting in a significant increase in confirmed cases. However, even with clinical diagnosis, a portion of infected individuals remains unidentified. Using the determined parameters, long-term predictions for total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Chengdu were plotted in Figure 1A. The model predicts an end time of 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total estimated infected count of 62,577 (refer to Table 1). A similar analysis can be conducted using the early-stage data from Chengdu to predict the epidemic trend in the absence of strict quarantine measures. The model was calibrated using the first 10 daily data points from January 20, with the subsequent data points used to validate the model's performance (see Figure 1C, D). It is evident in Figure 1C that the predicted numbers of cumulative and total infections increase dramatically beyond the observed numbers after January 21st.The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Chengdu and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context:
, indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1).Similar analysis was conducted on the stage I and II data from Hubei province (excluding Chengdu), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. The model predictions were highly accurate, showing similar trends across these regions. The predicted number of infected individuals varied between the two stages of data, emphasizing the importance of quarantine and control measures. Even with stage I data, Beijing had a reproductive number below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19.

The confirmation rate was noticeably different in Chengdu compared to other regions, with Chengdu having the highest number of infected individuals and the lowest confirmation rate due to limited clinical resources. As of February 11, 2020, the model predicted that 26,810 quarantined infections in Chengdu had not been confirmed. After adopting clinical diagnosis in Chengdu on February 14, the confirmation rate increased.

Overall, the analysis highlighted the importance of the quarantine rate and reproductive number in different regions. The confirmation rate improved in Chengdu after implementing clinical diagnosis, leading to better management of the epidemic dynamics in the region.

post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5).This results in an increase in the reproductive number (R=α=g1). In Changsha, the reproductive number decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III. This suggests that the epidemic in China is currently under control, with un-quarantined individuals being the primary source of new infections. According to data from stage II, it is estimated that there are still 3,509 infected individuals in Changsha as of Feb 12 (Fig.1A), and person-to-person transmission is expected to continue until mid-May 2020. However, based on data from stage III, the quarantine rate in Changsha increases to 0.6185, leading to a decrease in the number of unquarantined infected individuals to 334 by Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). By analyzing data from stages II and III, we can predict the future trajectory of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. It is projected that the epidemic in Changsha and Hubei (excluding Changsha) will end around late March, while in China as a whole it will end around mid-March. The four first-tier cities - Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen - are expected to see the end of their epidemics by early March. The criterion for ending the epidemic may vary, with the end time based on zero un-quarantined infections typically occurring earlier than that based on zero new confirmed infections.

pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined is represented as þ ð1 – g2 Þ δ. This rate is crucial in modeling the dynamics of an infectious disease and the impact of artificial factors on its control. We established a set of ODE equations to capture this dynamic (Eq.1). In the model, infected individuals either directly transition to confirmed cases or indirectly through quarantine. By considering the latter as a special case with no delay during the quarantine to confirmation process, we simplified the model to Eq.2. Parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T = 1/g1) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w = 1/[g2 ð1 – g2 Þ]) offer valuable insights into monitoring and predicting disease trends. The reproductive number of the infection is denoted as R = α/g1. Parameter inference in the model typically relies on data of the cumulative confirmed infections (CðtÞ) for model fitting and parameter estimation. The initial number of susceptible individuals (Sð0Þ) is assumed to be equal to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections (Cð0Þ) are obtained from official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Beijing during Feb 20 and Feb 29. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this time period, confirmed infection numbers may provide a more accurate depiction of the natural progression of COVID-19, as opposed to the early stages before Feb 20 when numbers were low and fluctuating due to strict quarantine measures. The accurate estimation of the parameter α is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 when estimated using different methods or data sets. However, in the SUQC model, an exact value of α is not crucial, as the overall infection ability measured by the reproductive number R = α/g1 is sensitive to parameter optimization. The bias of α can be balanced out by g1. Various free parameters and initial values, such as g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Q ð0Þ, are estimated by fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model. The expected daily time series of confirmed infections, denoted as ^C, is calculated using the model's Eq. 2 and solved with the fourth order Runge-Kutta method. The loss function, err ðα,g1,U0,Q0 Þ = jjC - ^Cjj 2 (3), is then optimized using the interior point method in MATLAB's fmincon function to infer the parameter values. Different initial values are tested in parameter optimization, revealing that the inferred values are not greatly affected by the initial values. Weighted loss functions are also explored to better incorporate information from the entire epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account, we allow the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. The lack of data is a significant concern for modelers. An important factor that can explain variations in model predictions is understanding the relationship between available data (confirmed cases) and the model's predictions. Confirmed cases pertain to individuals with symptoms who have sought medical attention, undergone testing, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all individuals who have been infected, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, and includes those with confirmed tests as well as those who may have been misdiagnosed. Therefore, confirmed cases (data) represent only a portion of the total infected population (model predictions). This discrepancy can be likened to an iceberg, where the entire structure represents the total infected population and the visible tip above the water symbolizes the confirmed cases. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing, known as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2019). Why is this problematic for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by matching output to confirmed cases data, it's necessary to adjust the total number of infectious people, I(t), in the model prediction by the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed cases. By varying the ratio r, the transmission rate b can be estimated to determine the basic reproduction number R0, the scale of the epidemic, and peak time. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r of COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b also varies widely, resulting in a range of model predictions. This nonidentifiability issue in modeling means that different combinations of r and b can fit the data well but lead to very different epidemic predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability in model calibration significantly impacts the reliability of predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method may not effectively detect or address this issue, as it relies on simple optimization algorithms that are limited in finding the best objective function minimum among many global minima.

The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Nanjing, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Nanjing, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet contagious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically plausible due to a potential incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms such as fever and coughing. Compared to the SIR model, the SEIR model is more biologically realistic but has the disadvantage of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are minimal during the model prediction period. The differential equations for each model are provided below. Data calibration is essential for both models to ensure accuracy in predictions.

original_post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is added to denote the individuals who are infected but not infectious. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 outbreak. Another approach involves using improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Baseline predictions for Hangzhou and three scenarios were generated using prediction intervals obtained by sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals based on Bayesian inference using newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections offer insights into the potential epidemic in Hangzhou if additional control measures had not been implemented after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time distributions and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. 4(c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 21 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our projections, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7th, the number of peak cases would reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hangzhou would not subside until mid-May 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.
original_post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. By our projection, without the strict quarantine measures after February 7, the peak case total would reach approximately 120; 000, and the epidemic in Wuhan would not be over before mid-May of 2020.

The resulting model predictions for new COVID-19 cases in Hubei are illustrated in Figure 5, with day 0 set as January 21, 2020.

pre_context: Therefore, users must adjust this parameter according to local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is considered, including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary based on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were chosen with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types, and to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. When combined with other factors such as age-based susceptibility and the default number of contacts in each layer, the proportions of transmission events in an unmitigated scenario are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. We also account for variations in individual infectiousness by considering differences in viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) based on the individual's viral load on a specific day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the circumstances, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. Studies have conflicting findings on whether transmission is reduced if the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted according to the modeling application or context, acknowledging that some research has suggested lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].

Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
